quiz.title: Grade 12 Advanced Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 1, Quiz 3.1: Advanced Vector Momentum Applications
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: Regarding the Railcar Cannon problem: A 1,500,000 kg car fires a 150 kg shell at 256 m/s at 33° above the horizontal. What is the recoil speed of the railcar?
questions.explanation: Conserve horizontal momentum ($p_x$): $0 = Mv_{car} + m(v_{shell} \cos 33^\circ)$. Thus, $v_{car} = (150 \times 256 \times \cos 33^\circ) / 1,500,000 \approx 0.0215$ m/s.

questions.question: In the image provided, a 2.3 kg ball hits a stationary 4.5 kg ball. After the collision, the 4.5 kg ball moves at 2.87 m/s at 21° North of East. What must be true about the initial velocity of the 2.3 kg ball?
options: It is the sum of the final x-components divided by the mass 2.3 kg.
It is equal to the total momentum of the 4.5 kg ball.
It is determined solely by the y-component of the 2.3 kg ball's final motion.
It is zero because momentum is only created during impact.
questions.explanation: Because the 2.3 kg ball was moving horizontally (East), the total initial momentum ($m_1v_1$) must equal the sum of the final x-components ($m_1v_{1x}' + m_2v_{2x}'$).

questions.question: When an object is hit by an impulse J at an angle to its original motion, the magnitude of the final momentum is found by:
options: The law of cosines or vector component addition.
Subtracting the work done from the kinetic energy.
Dividing the impulse by the time of contact.
questions.explanation: Since $\vec{p}_f = \vec{p}_i + \vec{J}$, vector addition rules apply. For non-parallel vectors, components or the law of cosines must be used.

questions.question: A 3.7 kg steel ball traveling East at 4.5 m/s collides with a stationary 8.4 kg aluminum ball. The steel ball rebounds at 1.4 m/s at 34° S of E. Calculate the final speed of the aluminum ball.
A 3.7 kg ball (4.5 m/s E) hits a stationary 8.4 kg ball. After impact, the 3.7 kg ball moves at 34° S of E. In what direction does the 8.4 kg ball move to conserve momentum?
questions.explanation: Using components: $p_{Al,x} = 12.36$ and $p_{Al,y} = 2.89$ (North). $\theta = \tan^{-1}(2.89 / 12.36) = 13.2^\circ$ North of East.

questions.question: A toy car moving North at 12 m/s strikes a stationary toy car of equal mass. Car 1 moves at 8.0 m/s at 30° E of N. What is the velocity of the second car?
In a collision between equal masses where Car 1 moves North and Car 2 is stationary, if Car 1 deflects East, what is the required direction of Car 2 to conserve x-momentum?
questions.explanation: Initial x-momentum is zero. If Car 1 gains Eastward momentum, Car 2 must gain an equal magnitude of Westward momentum to sum to zero.

questions.question: An object with an initial momentum is hit with an impulse of 12 N·s East, resulting in a final momentum of 42 kg·m/s at 43° N of E. What was the magnitude of the initial momentum?
A 150 kg shell is fired from a 1.5 million kg railcar at 256 m/s at 33° above the horizontal. Why is only the horizontal component ($v \cos 33^\circ$) used to find the car's recoil?
options: External forces from the tracks and ground prevent vertical recoil.
Vertical momentum is not conserved in projectile systems.
The mass of the car is too large for vertical motion to occur.
The launching force only acts horizontally.
questions.explanation: The car is constrained by tracks. The vertical impulse from the cannon is balanced by the upward normal force from the ground, so the car only moves horizontally.

questions.question: A 2.3 kg ball hits a stationary 4.5 kg ball. After impact, the 4.5 kg ball has a momentum of 12.9 kg·m/s at 21° N of E. If the 2.3 kg ball moves at 3.6 m/s at 34° S of E, calculate the initial speed of the 2.3 kg ball.
